title: 106_s2463
content: The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with most individuals facing capital charges unable to afford their own attorney and no state meeting ABA standards for indigent prisoner counsel. The American Bar Association (ABA) sets standards for the appointment, performance, and compensation of counsel for indigent prisoners. Evidence shows that the death penalty is disproportionately applied to certain racial and ethnic groups, with African-Americans making up a significant percentage of those executed and on death row. African-Americans account for a disproportionate percentage of those executed and on death row in the United States. Studies show that they make up a significant portion of defendants selected for capital prosecution. Studies have shown racial disparities in death penalty cases, with a high percentage of white victims and a majority of defendants selected for capital prosecution being African-American or Hispanic American. The General Accounting Office reported evidence of racial disparities in charging, sentencing, and imposition of the death penalty. In 1990, the General Accounting Office reported racial disparities in the death penalty system, with restrictions on prisoner appeals increasing the risk of wrongful imprisonment and execution. Since 1990, restrictions on prisoner appeals have increased the risk of wrongful imprisonment and execution, with the Supreme Court limiting death row prisoners' rights to appeal convictions and sentences in Federal courts. Legislation in 1996 further restricted Federal court review of death penalty appeals and reduced public funding for legal aid services for death row prisoners. The Federal Government and States are prohibited from carrying out the death penalty until Congress reviews the final findings and recommendations of the National Commission on the Death Penalty. This moratorium will remain in place until legislation is enacted based on the Commission's guidelines and procedures. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President in consultation with relevant officials. Members include Federal or State prosecutors and experienced attorneys. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members, including Federal or State prosecutors, attorneys experienced in capital defense, current or former judges, law enforcement officials, and individuals with knowledge or expertise from the public or private sector. The President designates one member to serve as the Chair, and the Commission adopts rules and procedures to govern its proceedings. SEC. 202. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is required to conduct a comprehensive study on the administration of the death penalty to ensure it aligns with constitutional principles and fairness. The study will include examining racial disparities and disproportionality in capital charging, prosecuting, and sentencing decisions. The Commission is mandated to study racial disparities and disproportionality in capital charging, prosecuting, and sentencing decisions, including adequacy of representation for capital defendants. The Commission is mandated to study racial disparities and disproportionality in capital charging, prosecuting, and sentencing decisions, including adequacy of representation for capital defendants. Factors considered include geographic location, income status, and adequacy of legal representation for capital defendants. The Commission studies racial disparities in capital cases, including adequacy of legal representation and wrongful convictions in death penalty cases. It also considers whether the Federal government should seek the death penalty in states without it and if courts are exercising independent judgment on constitutional merits. The Commission examines racial disparities, legal representation, and wrongful convictions in death penalty cases. It also debates the Federal government's role in seeking the death penalty in states without it, and the sentencing of mentally retarded and juvenile offenders to death. The Commission discusses issues such as racial disparities, legal representation, wrongful convictions, Federal government's role in seeking the death penalty, sentencing of mentally retarded and juvenile offenders to death, access to forensic evidence, and procedures to ensure fairness in death penalty cases. The Commission establishes guidelines and procedures to ensure fairness in death penalty cases, including access to forensic evidence and modern testing for new evidence of innocence. The Commission establishes guidelines and procedures to ensure fairness in death penalty cases, in accordance with the Constitution. The guidelines and procedures for administering the death penalty aim to ensure fairness, minimize the risk of executing innocent individuals, and prevent racial discrimination. A report is required within one year of establishing these guidelines. The Commission is tasked with ensuring due process, minimizing the risk of executing innocent individuals, and preventing racial discrimination in administering the death penalty. They are required to submit a preliminary report within one year and a final report within two years of the Act's enactment. The Commission must submit a preliminary report within one year and a final report within two years of the Act's enactment, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. SEC. 203. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission can obtain information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as necessary. The Commission can use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as needed to carry out its provisions. The Commission or its subcommittee can hold hearings, take testimony, and issue subpoenas to compel witnesses and evidence for carrying out its provisions. The Commission or its subcommittee can issue subpoenas to compel witnesses and evidence, with the Chairperson's signature required on the subpoenas for enforcement by designated individuals. The Chairperson of the Commission can issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence, which must be enforced by designated individuals. Failure to comply may result in a court order for testimony or evidence production, with contempt as a possible punishment. A court order may be issued for testimony or evidence production, with contempt as a possible punishment for failure to comply. Additionally, a court may issue a writ of habeas for testimony of a person held in custody. The court may issue a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to produce a person held in custody before the Commission. Witness allowances and fees are governed by section 1821. The Attorney General can request a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to bring a person before the Commission. Witness allowances and fees are regulated by section 1821 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation can be determined by the Chairperson and must be confirmed by the Commission. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and additional staff as needed. The executive director's compensation can be set by the Chairperson, subject to confirmation by the Commission, without following certain civil service laws. The Commission can appoint personnel without following certain civil service laws regarding classification and pay rates. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured as needed. The Chairperson of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services without exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status and privileges. SEC. 205. TERMINATION OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will end 90 days after submitting its report under section 202. SEC. 206. FUNDING. The Commission can spend up to $850,000 to carry out its duties, with funds provided by the Department of Justice.
